Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will complete a radial velocity and abundance survey of Solar Twin stars to test models of the importance of stellar metallicity to planet formation processes. The team will use the HARPS instrument and plans to estimate abundances more reliably than before using new observing and data reduction techniques. They have already been awarded four years of time for this project. One focus will be to concentrate on observing lithium and other refractory abundances in stars that greatly resemble the Sun.

Stars and their planets are thought to arise from the same fragment of a collapsed molecular cloud. Consequently, a star's properties likely reflect the physical conditions of the disk its planets formed in, and the study of relationships between planets' and their host stars' characteristics can give insight to the processes that govern planet formation and evolution. The observed strong positive correlation between stellar metallicity and giant planet frequency is an example of such a relationship. In astronomy, metallicity is generally defined as the abundance of all elements other than hydrogen and helium. Broader impacts of the work include training a graduate student in research, incorporating some of the data in undergraduate courses, an international collaboration with scientists in Brazil and Australia, and communicating with the public through articles on exoplanets in popular science magazines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have carried out a 5 year 100 night radial velocity search for planets around so-called "solar twin" stars. Solar twins are stars that are very similar to the Sun, and thus they enable very accurate characterization and comparison with the Sun. The motivation for this study was to explore how stellar compositions are related to the existence of planetary systems. We found a number of interesting planets and systems, including a rare twin of Jupiter (i.e., a gas giant orbiting at the same distance Jupiter does from our Sun) and a star that seems to have recently engulfed a significant amount of planetary material.

Perhaps the most interesting results to have come out of this project are from the studies of the compositions of the stars. We have found that stars in the solar neighborhood have very similar elemental abundance patterns. By abundance patterns we are talking about the ratios of elements, like carbon to oxygen and magnesium to silicon. This is very interesting because previous results suggested that stars have a fairly wide range of abundance patterns. Since we think that planets and stars formed together, we suspect that planets inherit the same ratio of elements as their stars. The fact that stars in the solar neighborhood have similar abundance patterns means that the planets around those stars likely have similar chemistries as the planets in our Solar System. We have also found that for all the similarities between stars in the solar neighborhood, the Sun stands out with a subtly different abundance pattern. The Sun appears deficient in rock-forming elements compared to other similar stars. This could be connected to the atypical system of planets that we live in compared to those that are seen around other stars. This finding will likely motivate further research to understand the Sun and our Solar System's place among their brethren.

Beyond scientific results, this grant enabled a number of broader impacts. A female graduate student did her PhD on this project and has recently joined the STEM workforce. The members of the team gave presentations on this work and exoplanet science in general in the local community and in YouTube videos. The PI also testified before a US congressional committee about exoplanet research.
